subject: Political Economy
statement_full_text:
Why do you want to study Political Economy?

Knowing how incentives build social value or lead to collective inefficiencies intrigues me. An example I've seen: Asian Marriage Markets.

Parents see people as commodities, whose value later depreciates, and rush to match suitors early, making the market congested. This means too many compete for the same resource simultaneously, despite having incomplete information, leading to worse matches and market inefficiency, as parents hastily accept any match. This shows how perverse incentives (parents' fears) lead to market failure. The adverse effect cultural norms have on systems like marriage makes me interested in political economy.

Roth's Who Gets What & Why, taught me how mechanism design adapts incentives in systems to achieve social benefits. I learnt how to fix congested markets e.g. lawyer internships, where early matches lead to inefficiency, by reducing incentives to match early/encouraging people to go later, building trust and cooperation. However, I found limits e.g. public opposition and cheating, reveal gaps between policies' viability and economic design, drawing me into political economy.

I wish to study institutional design, incentives and Game Theory in political economy to tackle tyranny of the majority (where majority preference exceeds minorities') and rentierism (where monopolistic land ownership reduces allocative efficiency, driving inequality).

How have your qualifications and studies helped you to prepare for Political Economy?

Dittrich's 2007 paper, taught me the value of the Kalai Smorodinsky Solution (KSS) in wage negotiations. This is a bargaining tool used to share scarce resources relative to people's desires rather than an equal split.

I learnt that in dual labour markets, where unions negotiate wages with KSS vs firms using Nash bargaining, using the KSS can lead to higher employment and fairer wages. This is because workers face pay increases relative to the firm's profits and their bargaining power, leading to less strikes, and productivity gains. However, I think the KSS ignores information asymmetry in large labour markets as firms may know more about profits than workers.

Later, I wrote about Game Theory in Rocket League (RL). It is a game where players compete, taking a share of the field in positioning. Information gaps between teammates make sharing this resource hard. I designed a bidding mechanism for sharing space on the field, so each player's preference is revealed and respected, leading to better resource allocation. Learning information revelation and fair institutional design drives me towards political economy.

What else have you done to prepare outside of education, and why are these experiences useful?

CH2 Radical Markets introduced me to Weyl's Quadratic Voting (QV) in elections. He argues QV makes it cost more to use more votes, so only those passionate and educated on issues vote on them. While he assumes voters are rationally passionate, I believe misinformation sways intensity of preference. Uneducated voters passionate about Brexit will choose to spend votes on this, so most will vote for Brexit, expanding tyranny of the majority. Policymakers have little incentive to promote QV, as a one person one vote system preserves their power, so Weyl may face dissent, unless he can align incentives. I wish to study incentive alignment, public and social choice theory in political economy.

Richard Green's paper Elecxit led me to electricity-market coupling and how Brexit disrupted UK-EU integration. My key finding was that Brexit halting automatic electricity transfer meant UK-EU power stations failed to transmit/receive correct amounts, causing €300m+ dynamic losses, due to risk-averse investors, showing me the limits of social choice on electricity markets

Interviewing him on nationalising British energy improved my knowledge of how political economy concepts e.g. government minimum price buffers reduce investor risk in asset ownership.

feedback_items.your_feedback: There's not a lot of politics in there, it's very economicsy. If you're applying for PPE, you need to talk about politics, philosophy, and economics. You need to redo those sections to add more of a politics twist.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Add substantial politics content to balance the economics focus, especially for PPE applications

feedback_items.your_feedback: The whole thing is underdeveloped and underexplained. It makes you look like you're just throwing in theories into random examples, forcing complex theories into examples where they don't really fit.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Develop each section more fully and ensure theories naturally fit the examples rather than being forced

feedback_items.weak_passage: Parents see people as commodities, whose value later depreciates, and rush to match suitors early, making the market congested.
feedback_items.your_feedback: The marriage market example doesn't work. It's an overly simplistic way to explain what isn't even a very difficult concept. You're hypothesizing and forcing in concepts like people as commodities and depreciation without backing it up with data. You haven't provided any evidence of actual market failure.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: If you keep this example, expand it fully with a study showing before/after results when removing this incentive. Include data proving parents' fears lead to market failure. Otherwise, choose a different example.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Roth's Who Gets What & Why, taught me how mechanism design adapts incentives in systems to achieve social benefits. I learnt how to fix congested markets e.g. lawyer internships
feedback_items.your_feedback: This part about Roth reads like a set of notes rather than developed analysis. You're just listing points - 'for example, lawyer internships' is so simplified. It feels like you've just summarized rather than demonstrated deep engagement.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Develop this into a full section with a specific game theory puzzle from a good text, explain the technical setup, discuss a variation, and apply it to a real-life article that uses that game model

feedback_items.weak_passage: I wish to study institutional design, incentives and Game Theory in political economy to tackle tyranny of the majority
feedback_items.your_feedback: This conclusion is just a thought rather than a developed point. It doesn't follow naturally from what came before and needs more building up.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Link this ambition more clearly to the preceding examples and develop why these specific areas matter

feedback_items.weak_passage: Dittrich's 2007 paper, taught me the value of the Kalai Smorodinsky Solution (KSS) in wage negotiations. This is a bargaining tool used to share scarce resources relative to people's desires rather than an equal split.
feedback_items.your_feedback: The KSS section feels like a set of notes. It's just a summary of how it works without explaining wider impacts for society or why you're writing about this in the first place. If you're doing PPE, you need more of a politics twist anyway.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Expand this section significantly. Go more into the maths - look at optimization problems, different graphs, and ways of modeling this. Get into the nitty-gritty of the maths, then link it to something current like TFL strikes.

feedback_items.your_feedback: This paper is a bit niche for answering 'why do you want to study the subject?' It doesn't clearly connect to your broader motivation.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I wrote about Game Theory in Rocket League (RL). It is a game where players compete, taking a share of the field in positioning.
feedback_items.your_feedback: The Rocket League example isn't bad if you explain precisely how it works with stronger technical detail. But as it is, it's forcing something in just to show you can apply theories to real life. Choosers really dislike taking theory and making it work in a practical sense - the whole point is that this is academic and theoretical.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: If you keep this, expand it significantly to make it a proper project. Make it a lot more technical and developed with precise explanations of how the mechanism works.

feedback_items.weak_passage: CH2 Radical Markets introduced me to Weyl's Quadratic Voting (QV) in elections. He argues QV makes it cost more to use more votes
feedback_items.your_feedback: The quadratic voting section feels a bit random - where is this coming from? It's confusing how this ties in. The problem comes from not enough sources rather than anything else.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Develop this more and bring in another point of view. Add more sources to support your discussion.

feedback_items.weak_passage: My key finding was that Brexit halting automatic electricity transfer meant UK-EU power stations failed to transmit/receive correct amounts, causing €300m+ dynamic losses
feedback_items.your_feedback: That's not really a finding so much as a result that you can comment on. Your conclusion about showing 'the limits of social choice' isn't very strong either.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Expand the Richard Green interview section significantly - what did you ask him? What did he say? Go into detail. This is a fantastic opportunity that deserves more space. Develop it question by question with more technical explanation and knowledge.
feedback_items.strong_passage: Interviewing him on nationalising British energy
feedback_items.why_strong: This sounds really interesting and is a fantastic opportunity that could be expanded into a strong section showing original research and expert engagement.

feedback_items.your_feedback: You're the only person so far who has too little filler sentences and language. You actually need a bit more to say 'this is why I want to study it' throughout.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Add more linking language and full sentences explaining your motivations and why you want to study these topics

feedback_items.your_feedback: You're smart and understanding high-level papers and theory, which is good. Your level of understanding and knowledge base is better than what this brings across. I'm being harsh because I can tell how smart you are and how it's coming across - and from somebody reading these all the time, this doesn't sound smart.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: With just added linking sentences, this is not a bad effort at all. But to make it super academic, you need to make the suggested changes about development and structure.
feedback_items.why_strong: You are smart and clearly understanding quite high-level papers, theory, and have clearly understood it, which is good.

subject: Politics and Economics
statement_full_text:
PS Draft #7

Q1

As counselling for pupils fell and detentions rose at my school, I questioned why teachers sought to tackle misbehaviour with detentions rather than addressing the apparent root causes: poor mental health and student wellbeing. This seemingly revealed a trend where policymakers favour politically simple, short-term control over complex long-term investment in welfare. My suspicions were aroused further after learning from DC Black's 2021 Review of Drugs, Part Two, that while the total cost to society of illegal drugs is £20 bn annually, only £650m was spent on treatment and prevention. This is despite the fact that every £1 spent on harm reduction and treatment gave a combined return on investment of £4. Amazed by this misallocation of resources, I wanted to find out why economically viable policies are discarded for more politically favourable ones by studying politics & economics at university.

Q2

To begin with, Roth's work on repugnant markets showed me how social opposition may block efficient but taboo solutions. I thought this was best applicable to debates regarding asylum seekers in the UK. Despite findings from the National Institute of Economic and Social Research that allowing them to work would increase tax revenue by £1.3bn and reduce government spending by £6.7bn, this has been blocked by policymakers. It was the dilemma of integrating politics into market design which led me to Shengwu Li's stance: informed neutrality between reasonable ethical positions and focusing on objective goals like efficiency in market design. Although I agree that objective goals should be prioritised, the act of defining "reasonable ethical positions is not neutral. Thus, market designers can not be neutral in practice and must consider social norms and fairness.

Applying mechanism design to social choice debates, I came across Weyl's Radical Markets, which proposes using Quadratic Voting (QV) in elections. He argues that QV means it costs quadratically more to cast votes, so only those who feel truly intensely about an issue will vote on it and internalise the social cost caused by their vote. However, I believe that misinformation can distort intensity of preference on topical issues like immigration and so undermines QV's outcomes and efficiency. Weyl theoretically assumes intensity of preference to be an exogenous variable, when it is in reality often endogenous. This was echoed by Kaplow & Kominers' 2017 paper, which argued social movements and misconceptions can make voters act irrationally under QV. I wish to use econometrics at university to consider the effect external actors can have on voter rationality in public choice settings.

Q3

Interviewing Prof. Richard Green of Imperial on the impacts on consumers and firms of building Sizewell C introduced me to the Regulated Asset Base Model (RAB): Ownership is used for projects like Sizewell C, where investors are given a fixed return, as consumers absorb construction costs. However, he argued that this would not use a cost-plus model, and the government would have to compensate investors while protecting consumers by agreeing on a fair energy price. From this, I now realise the role the government plays in reducing risk among investors and maintaining social welfare, which I wish to explore further in politics & economics.

Participating in a one-week UNIQ PPE taster course at Oxford University, where I attended lectures and wrote essays on utilitarianism, familiarised me with university-level work and improved my essay writing and time management skills. Moreover, St James's Place's wealth management work experience taught me how behavioural economics affected investment decisions and the key analytical skills that I will need to engage with political and economic theory. Participating in charity camping via Scouts has deepened my devotion to outreach as I aspire to be a leading member of my university community.

feedback_items.weak_passage: As counselling for pupils fell and detentions rose at my school, I questioned why teachers sought to tackle misbehaviour with detentions rather than addressing the apparent root causes
feedback_items.your_feedback: Okay paragraph but bit wordy still considering it's quite a descriptive paragraph - too many words for what is ultimately quite a simple conclusion and all coming from you as opposed to interesting source material.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Be more concise and incorporate more external source material rather than personal observations

feedback_items.weak_passage: This seemingly revealed a trend where policymakers favour politically simple, short-term control over complex long-term investment in welfare.
feedback_items.your_feedback: It's a bit simplified - it's not really only about economically viable vs politically favourable. You've just chosen to see it that way. There will be a multitude of factors determining where money is spent, not necessarily a misallocation.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Acknowledge the complexity of policy decisions and avoid reducing them to a single binary explanation

feedback_items.weak_passage: As counselling for pupils fell and detentions rose at my school... DC Black's 2021 Review of Drugs
feedback_items.your_feedback: Technically, detentions in school vs mental health counselling does not parallel your drugs example where you are looking at ROI and actual spend. Also, it's not exactly that policies are discarded so much as underfunded according to your drug example.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Ensure your examples parallel each other properly or adjust your framing from 'discarded' to 'underfunded'

feedback_items.weak_passage: It was the dilemma of integrating politics into market design which led me to Shengwu Li's stance: informed neutrality between reasonable ethical positions and focusing on objective goals like efficiency in market design.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Better but still - you could explain Shengwu Li's point more. Interesting that you've brought up 'informed neutrality between... in market design'... so what? Where do you see this applied? You need a sentence between this and then your conclusions otherwise unclear.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Add a sentence between introducing Li's concept and drawing your conclusions. Show where this concept is applied to bridge the gap.

feedback_items.weak_passage: To begin with, Roth's work on repugnant markets showed me how social opposition may block efficient but taboo solutions.
feedback_items.your_feedback: You should consider the link between this and repugnant markets more, otherwise it seems like a throwaway. Might be worth clarifying meaning of repugnant markets more as well. Is asylum seeker a repugnant market example?
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Clarify what repugnant markets means and strengthen the connection to your asylum seeker example

feedback_items.your_feedback: This is close to being a very strong paragraph but slight underdevelopment plus not flowing perfectly is taking it from a 9 to a 7.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Develop slightly more and improve the flow between ideas to reach top-tier quality

feedback_items.weak_passage: Applying mechanism design to social choice debates, I came across Weyl's Radical Markets, which proposes using Quadratic Voting (QV) in elections.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This paragraph is very good.
feedback_items.strong_passage: Applying mechanism design to social choice debates, I came across Weyl's Radical Markets, which proposes using Quadratic Voting (QV) in elections. He argues that QV means it costs quadratically more to cast votes, so only those who feel truly intensely about an issue will vote on it and internalise the social cost caused by their vote. However, I believe that misinformation can distort intensity of preference on topical issues like immigration and so undermines QV's outcomes and efficiency. Weyl theoretically assumes intensity of preference to be an exogenous variable, when it is in reality often endogenous. This was echoed by Kaplow and Kominers' 2017 paper, which argued social movements and misconceptions can make voters act irrationally under QV. I wish to use econometrics at university to consider the effect external actors can have on voter rationality in public choice settings.
feedback_items.why_strong: This paragraph demonstrates sophisticated understanding of quadratic voting, provides critical analysis with supporting sources, and connects to future academic interests.

feedback_items.weak_passage: However, he argued that this would not use a cost-plus model
feedback_items.your_feedback: If not a cost-plus model, what is it? Investors are given a fixed return and consumers absorb construction costs?
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Clarify what model is being used if not cost-plus, and explain the relationship between investor returns and consumer costs more clearly

feedback_items.weak_passage: From this, I now realise the role the government plays in reducing risk among investors and maintaining social welfare
feedback_items.your_feedback: Conclusion is a bit nothing - 'I realise the role the government plays'... Can you think of something else there?
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Replace with a more substantive conclusion that demonstrates deeper insight

feedback_items.weak_passage: Participating in a one-week UNIQ PPE taster course at Oxford University, where I attended lectures and wrote essays on utilitarianism, familiarised me with university-level work and improved my essay writing and time management skills. Moreover, St James's Place's wealth management work experience taught me how behavioural economics affected investment decisions
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is just a list of achievements which is usually fine but quite a large paragraph! Consider removing the taster course section and expanding what you mean by 'behavioural economics affected investment decisions' to make this a proper section. In your case, the first option sounds more interesting.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Remove the UNIQ course mention and expand the behavioural economics section into a proper developed paragraph. Ask tutor to put the other bit into your reference.

subject: Economics
statement_full_text:
Question 1: Why do you want to study this course or subject?
What makes a decision rational: its intention, its outcome, or its impact on others?
When considering the field of economics, there are underlying assumptions of ceteris paribus and rational economic agents acting in their best interests. However, in reality, this may not true. This piqued my interest in behavioural economics, in particular, how logic gaps contradict the idea of rationality, which underpins all economic theories. What intrigues me the most is how firms are monetising these biases to shape consumer preference to maximise sales.
Reading Kahneman's "Thinking Fast and Slow", I was surprised to see the frequency at which we succumb to our cognitive biases. Kahneman redefined human decision making into two systems: the fast, intuitive System 1 and the slow, analytical System 2. I was particularly interested in how System 1 uses heuristics such as anchoring to influence their decisions. Listening to Freakonomics Radio, I was introduced to left digit bias, a form of anchoring where consumers fixate on the left-most digit. This leads to irrational differences in perceived value, challenging the classical economic assumption of rationality. Having independently studied Prospect Theory, I was convinced that consumers' decisions were driven by the fear of losing. Professor Abeler's research paper "Reference Points and Effort Provision" was able to give key insights into how this was the case. The paper demonstrated the role of loss aversion when it came to behaviour. People are motivated when they are expected to fall short of a target, often leading to choices influenced more by emotion than logic. When applying this to society, I have seen how firms leverage loss aversion through limited- time deals to encourage impulsive purchases and ultimately, these maximise profit.
In exploring the intersection between behavioural economics and economic history, I researched key historical events that highlighted the limitations of rationality. After listening to an LSE podcast "Ten Years after the Crisis", I was fascinated by the role herd behaviour played in the Financial Crisis. Investors were mimicking the actions of others, rather than their own independent analysis creating asset bubbles and the collapse of the market. This gives an insight into how psychological factors can affect market outcomes. What was most interesting is how the Financial Crisis echoes previous events, leading to the same devastating economic consequences. 
I look forward to exploring consumer behaviour and historical economic patterns in the  behavioural economics module.

How have your qualifications and studies helped you to prepare for this course or subject?
Mathematics is an important foundation for economics. I find it extremely rewarding when applying mathematical models to abstract economic theories to form empirical results. Having read "Mathematics for Economics and Finance" by Anthony and Biggs introduced me to the Lagrange Multiplier method- a technique to maximise profit when facing constraints from the basic problem of scarcity. By measuring the value of relaxing these constraints, firms can gain an insight into how much additional profit could be made. I find it fascinating how firms can use this concept to succeed in a market, through applying real world limitations such as regulations and budgets, often disregarded in traditional economic theory. From a profit-maximising perspective, firms are able to create mathematical models which are adapted for innate consumer biases such as accounting for their elasticity in the Third-Degree Price Discrimination. I am particularly interested in how managerial styles are influenced by a firm's ambitious goals with practical outcomes centred around data and models. To further my understanding, I attended lectures at the Marshall Conference 2025 at the University of Cambridge, including one given by Professor Nejra van Zalk on Surveillance Capitalism. Her arguments further challenged what I had previously learnt – firms tactically nudge consumers to their products. Surveillance Capitalism is utilised by firms to tailor advertisements and create an echo chamber to shape the decisions of consumers, demonstrating a trend towards a digital economy. Firms are beginning to focus on digital surveillance as a profitable model to influence the public in a certain direction irrespective of rationality. 
Economic theory can help to explain the political climate of a country. I was selected for the University of Bath's Economics Pathway where I regularly participated in online lectures on macroeconomic concepts. My dissertation on the comparative analysis of government responses to the COVID -19 pandemic and Russia-Ukraine War, and their impacts on national economies received a First Class Honours. I applied the IS-LM model to assess shifts in economic performance during each crisis with particular emphasis on inflation and consumer uncertainty, learning how both the pandemic and war impacted economies differently via demand and supply respectively. I was shocked to learn the vulnerability of larger economies due to their interdependence on each other. This drives my study into past economic events how they inform current decision making. 

What else have you done to prepare outside of education, and why are these experiences useful?
Over the past year, I have been working independently towards a Level 2 Fundamentals in Financial Services qualification by the CISI, for which I achieved 28/30. I have expanded my knowledge about key financial instruments, for example, bonds, equities and derivatives. During my insight day at CitiBank, I was able to examine the use of these instruments and risk management strategies used by the firm when executing a trade. I observed the purchase of a forward for a French bond deepening my interest in how management strategically balances risk and profit for themselves and the client. 
I enjoyed competing in the UKMT Senior Mathematics Challenge achieving a Gold Award. The Ritangle 2024 Competition was an opportunity for me to apply my coding skills to weekly mathematics problems, where I led my team to the final stage. I have been successful in both individual and team-based competitions, developing a skill set suitable for the various styles of university-level studying. 
My role as Vice Chair within the Finance Committee, in particular, launching an initiative for Year 12 students, gave me an opportunity to consolidate my understanding of economic concepts when presenting these to fellow students, for which I received positive feedback from both teachers and students. I have also gained a certificate for Bloomberg Finance Fundamentals, where I learnt about the flow of money and the finance sector.

feedback_items.your_feedback: I don't think it works particularly well for econ history. LSE obviously care more about the personal statement than Oxford. If you're trying to make a choice, I would personally write it toward an LSE degree, so basically not including so much about management.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Focus the statement on LSE's requirements and remove management content if not applying to Economics and Management specifically

feedback_items.your_feedback: The biggest problem is that this is basically a summary. What you've done here is summary-type writing. It's not quite like a high level personal statement. Even though the writing itself is not bad, it all feels a little bit more like notes that you've put together.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Transform from summary-style writing to high-level analytical writing that demonstrates depth rather than breadth

feedback_items.weak_passage: When considering the field of economics, there are underlying assumptions of ceteris paribus and rational economic agents acting in their best interests. However, in reality, this may not true.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This doesn't sound that smart because these underlying assumptions are so basic. You could really just say math is made up of numbers. That's kind of what it sounds like. All you've really said is 'we have some models that we use in the economy and I think behavioural economics is interesting.'
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Skip the obvious intro and get straight to super high level behavioural economics content. This entire first paragraph could be cut.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Kahneman redefined human decision making into two systems: the fast, intuitive System 1 and the slow, analytical System 2.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Kahneman's Thinking Fast and Slow is very well used. I would personally just assume they know System 1, System 2, and get a higher level conclusion out of that rather than explaining what they are. It's kind of not that interesting because his work is so famous. Bringing something else out of it will do you a better service.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Assume knowledge of System 1/System 2 and jump to a higher-level application or insight about economy and System 2 thinking

feedback_items.weak_passage: I was particularly interested in how System 1 uses heuristics such as anchoring to influence their decisions. Listening to Freakonomics Radio, I was introduced to left digit bias
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is just like a definition of his work and left digit bias. It's just not interesting because it is just like a definition. It doesn't link to you exploring further and finding something else where this is applied with massive ramifications. It's just 'I read this and this is what it is.'
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: After introducing concepts, show where you explored further - find an application with significant implications and develop that

feedback_items.weak_passage: After listening to an LSE podcast "Ten Years after the Crisis", I was fascinated by the role herd behaviour played in the Financial Crisis.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This whole thing is not that academic. It's interesting, but it's a thought rather than academic analysis. If you could make it academic, bring in something mathematical - look at modelling. That would make the whole thing a lot more interesting because the topic itself is good, it's just the way you've gone about it.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Add mathematical modeling or quantitative analysis to make this section academic rather than just interesting commentary

feedback_items.weak_passage: Mathematics is an important foundation of economics. I find it extremely rewarding when applying mathematical models to abstract economic theories to form empirical results.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Those two sentences are fine, keep them if you like. But it's better just to apply those models, abstract theories, and give me some results.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Keep or cut these sentences, but move quickly to actually showing the application rather than stating you do it

feedback_items.weak_passage: Having read "Mathematics for Economics and Finance" by Anthony and Biggs introduced me to the Lagrange Multiplier method- a technique to maximise profit when facing constraints from the basic problem of scarcity.
feedback_items.your_feedback: The Lagrange multiplier is good for a first year university concept. But this is summary stuff - measuring the value of these constraints, firms can gain insights. It all kind of reads as like a summary of what they're going to look at on the degree.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Rather than summarizing what the method does, demonstrate why you'd be a good student on the degree through deeper analysis

feedback_items.your_feedback: This whole paragraph has the potential to be really interesting. It is clear that you know your stuff and you've done a lot of work. But the conclusions and development you're doing is a little bit like... you can do better. I can tell you probably have other points you can make, but you've chosen these because you think they sound most proper or clean. Push the boat out a little bit because you're not doing yourself a service.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Make bolder, more sophisticated arguments rather than safe, clean points. Show the depth you're capable of.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I was selected for the University of Bath's Economics Pathway where I regularly participated in online lectures on macroeconomic concepts. My dissertation on the comparative analysis of government responses to the COVID -19 pandemic and Russia-Ukraine War, and their impacts on national economies received a First Class Honours.
feedback_items.your_feedback: That's crazy to have done at your age. I would personally expand upon that. This whole paragraph I thought was really good actually, because it's really interesting. This sounds like university level stuff - a dissertation is a serious deal. I would probably dedicate a lot more space to that and expand upon research, what kind of data you collected, and all of that stuff. So that's fantastic.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Significantly expand this section with details about your research methodology, data collection, and findings. This is a huge accomplishment that deserves more space.
feedback_items.strong_passage: I was selected for the University of Bath's Economics Pathway where I regularly participated in online lectures on macroeconomic concepts. My dissertation on the comparative analysis of government responses to the COVID -19 pandemic and Russia-Ukraine War, and their impacts on national economies received a First Class Honours. I applied the IS-LM model to assess shifts in economic performance during each crisis with particular emphasis on inflation and consumer uncertainty, learning how both the pandemic and war impacted economies differently via demand and supply respectively.
feedback_items.why_strong: This is a huge accomplishment for someone your age - university-level dissertation work showing serious research capability and sophisticated economic analysis.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Over the past year, I have been working independently towards a Level 2 Fundamentals in Financial Services qualification by the CISI
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is a bit more random, a bit like 'OK, they'll probably be OK with this.' It won't be a plus though. Stuff like that is not a plus - it's too vocational, and LSE and Oxford are obviously very academic.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Consider removing or significantly reducing vocational qualifications. Ask tutor to mention in reference instead.

feedback_items.weak_passage: During my insight day at CitiBank, I was able to examine the use of these instruments and risk management strategies
feedback_items.your_feedback: This kind of stuff is not a plus. It's too vocational. They think you'll be able to do that anyway - anybody should be able to. So it's not particularly interesting.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Remove or significantly condense. This doesn't add academic value for Oxbridge applications.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I have been successful in both individual and team-based competitions, developing a skill set suitable for the various styles of university-level studying.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This kind of sentence you don't need in there - they'll know that. If you have that stuff written in the reference saying I'm a very good team player, you know, that's better.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Delete this sentence and ask tutor to include teamwork skills in reference instead

feedback_items.weak_passage: My role as Vice Chair within the Finance Committee, in particular, launching an initiative for Year 12 students, gave me an opportunity to consolidate my understanding
feedback_items.your_feedback: That's fine, but I'd probably reduce that into like one or two sentences. The Bloomberg Financial fundamentals, you can mention it and say like I do that in my spare time.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Condense final achievements into 1-2 sentences maximum

feedback_items.your_feedback: Your writing style as a whole is quite wordy. There are times where I look at your sentence and I'm like, I could have said that in about 4 words.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Take a critical view of your writing and cut length down significantly. Be more concise throughout.

feedback_items.your_feedback: Overall, you're clearly smart. You clearly know your stuff and clearly put the work in. It's good. It's not a bad statement, it's not wrong, it's just it could be better. If you could push it out a bit more with different examples and conclusions, it would improve significantly.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Look for opportunities to make bolder arguments and demonstrate the depth you're capable of rather than playing it safe
feedback_items.why_strong: You're clearly smart, clearly know your stuff, and clearly put the work in.

subject: Economics
statement_full_text:
1.Why do you want to study this course or subject?
For a Lloyds Bank Challenge, I analysed customer data to set credit limits in Year 10. I found it fascinating that banks use vast datasets to model diverse factors ranging from personal (income, debt), and organisational (risk appetite) to macro level (economic outlook) to arrive at a single number i.e. interest rate.
It was interesting to further read about yield curves and bond prices from Bank of England educational resources as it showed interpretation of data to reveal important signals e.g. use of yield curve as market's opinion on credibility of government's fiscal and monetary policies as well as economic forecast with upward slope signalling growth and inverted curves pointing to contraction.
I want to study Economics as I am curious about use of information, data and economic theory to understand and predict how societies, markets and countries make decisions and adapt in complex conditions.

2.How have your qualifications and studies helped you to prepare for this course or subject?
As a finalist in Maths for Morality course run by "leaf.courses" I learnt to model resource allocation problem by calculating "impact per dollar" relative score for a range of issues such as extreme poverty and animal welfare. This was done by breaking the calculation into individual components i.e. Scale (Impact/% change in problem), Solvability (% change in problem/% change in resources) and Neglectedness (% change in resources/$), and then multiplying them back together. Using supplied data, the calculation led me to numbers of various magnitude - a problem I solved by use of logarithmic scaling where 10x difference would equal 1 unit, like "Richter Scale". The Q&A session on my work taught me importance of stating my assumptions, clarifying uncertainties in data as well supporting my work with qualitative analysis.
I explored the topic of "Socio-economic challenge of AI" in my entry to Northeastern University's essay competition, where I was a top 20% finalist. As a result, I learnt about the modified Cobb-Douglas function, which uses capital, labour, human capital inputs along with their respective elasticities and tech-factor to predict economic output. On qualitative side I argued that AI will improve output due to uplift in "Human Capital" & "Tech-Factor" as it lowers the barriers by providing substitute for expertise and skills not available otherwise. On quantitative side, I used Solow's Growth Model to assess the tech factor as function of time and tech growth rate: A(t) = A​.e^λt. I created different graph plots by assuming different growth rates for a 5-year period to visualise significant impact of AI. Reading several papers from PwC, Accenture and EU parliament etc. also revealed challenges related to job losses, stressed labour relations & disruption in economy.
For University of Oxford's Big Think essay competition, I created a framework to assess the topic "With rise of AI, do we need managers?" and won the Economics & Management category. I focussed on Mintzberg's interpretation of managerial jobs as falling into interpersonal, informational, and decisional roles. I referenced an IMF research paper "AI and the Future of Work" to argue that by plotting "exposure" and "complementarity" (i.e. shielding from AI) on coordinate axes, jobs can be divided into 4 quadrants. I then evaluated risk of job losses based on the quadrant where different jobs may lie depending on their alignment with Mintzberg's roles. I further argued that new labour dynamics will emerge based on factors such as worker identity and societal acceptance of automation.

3.What else have you done to prepare outside of education, and why are these experiences useful?
While studying market failure in Economics, I was struck by the contrasting views of Eugene Fama & Robert Shiller on markets. To explore Fama's ideas, I used Essentials of Investments by Bodie/Kane to build a CAPM project. Working through questions in the book helped me grasp the concept of returns, variance, covariance, and the use of log returns. I used R/RStudio to download dataset of monthly returns of five stocks alongside Fama-French factors to run excess-return regressions and estimate CAPM (alpha,beta) for each stock and then evaluated fit of charts against actual data. This exercise made it fascinating to read Shiller's critique of efficient market hypothesis as he challenges assumption of frictionless markets and highlights information asymmetry. It helped me appreciate the way foundational knowledge of economics and finance evolves over time and makes me look forward to discovering more as part of my university degree.

feedback_items.your_feedback: Much better - the only weak section is paragraph 1.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Focus improvements on the opening section

I found it fascinating that banks use vast datasets to model diverse factors ranging from personal (income, debt), and organisational (risk appetite) to macro level (economic outlook) to arrive at a single number i.e. interest rate.

subject: Economics and Finance
statement_full_text:
1.Why do you want to study this course or subject?
A Year 10 challenge with Lloyds Banking Group gave me my first insight into financial systems as I analysed customer data to set credit limits. Discovering how interest rates reflect lending risk and balance the needs of different groups sparked my fascination with economics.
It was not long before I was reading Bank of England resources on yield curves and impact of bond prices on economy as the negative effects of Liz Truss's budget became visible. The link between Economics, Finance, and daily life could not have been starker.
I want to study Economics and Finance to channel my curiosity about how societies and economies function. By focusing on Econometrics, Microeconomics and Financial Markets, I hope to understand how individuals, societies, markets and countries make decisions and adapt in complex conditions.

2.How have your qualifications and studies helped you to prepare for this course or subject?
I learnt quantitative methods to model abstract concepts such as scale of extreme poverty vs. impact of covid as a finalist in selective Maths for Morality course run by leaf.courses. I calculated relative scores by multiplying probability rating with expected benefits. However, this produced numbers of varying magnitude - a problem I solved by use of logarithmic scaling to build a "Richter Scale" like scoring where a unit difference represented 10x difference. I learnt the limitation of this model were that relatively small difference in probability data produced wildly different scores, and results were difficult to explain as logarithmic scale hid vast differences. These challenges made me curious about models and data used to predict scale of impact of one of the most disruptive technologies i.e. AI.
I explored this in my entry to Northeastern University's essay competition on Economics, where I was a top 20% finalist. Follow up research into modified Cobb-Douglas function (Y = A(t).K^α.L^β.H^γ), showed me the use of capital, labour, human capital and tech factor, along with their respective elasticities, to predict the economic output. Modelling tech factor as function of time with different rates of AI growth revealed accelerated output growth, often touted by several sources. However, on more research I realised limits of this model due to multicollinearity and impact of tech factor on human capital which could well be negative due to job losses, stressed labour relations & disruption in economy. 
I further researched above pain-point in my entry to the Oxford University's "Big Think" essay competition where I won the Economics & Management category. I picked Mintzberg's interpretation of managerial job as mix of Interpersonal, Informational and Decisional roles and combined it with ideas of "exposure" and "complementarity" (i.e. shielding from AI) from IMF's research paper on "AI and Future of Work". I built my own framework where I assigned exposure and complementarity to the coordinate axes and placed Mintzberg's roles in different quadrants to support my argument. I further extended this framework arguing that labour dynamics depend on worker identity and societal acceptance of automation.
Separately, I explored how disruptive patents incentivize tech expansion while creating consumer welfare loss. Using Farrel and Shapiro's framework from "The Economics of information technology" to quantify consumer surplus, I found that while this drives R&D spending, it risks monopoly pricing, highlighting regulators' crucial role in balancing innovation incentives with consumer interests.

3.What else have you done to prepare outside of education, and why are these experiences useful?
While studying market failure in Economics, I was struck by the contrasting views of Eugene Fama & Robert Shiller on markets. To explore Fama's ideas, I used Essentials of Investments by Bodie/Kane to build a CAPM project. Working through questions in the book helped me grasp the concept of returns, variance, covariance, and the use of log returns. I used R/RStudio to download dataset of monthly returns of five stocks alongside Fama-French factors to run excess-return regressions and estimate CAPM (alpha, beta) for each stock and then evaluated fit of charts against actual data. This exercise made it fascinating to read Shiller's critique of efficient market hypothesis as he challenges assumption of frictionless markets and highlights information asymmetry. It helped me appreciate the way foundational knowledge of economics and finance evolves over time and makes me look forward to discovering more as part of my university degree.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Discovering how interest rates reflect lending risk and balance the needs of different groups sparked my fascination with economics.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Fine but quite wordy for saying quite a simple idea. Interest rates of course reflect lending risks. What do you mean by interest rates 'balance the needs of different groups' - this is not clear.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Be more concise and clarify what you mean by 'balance the needs of different groups'

feedback_items.weak_passage: It was not long before I was reading Bank of England resources on yield curves and impact of bond prices on economy as the negative effects of Liz Truss's budget became visible. The link between Economics, Finance, and daily life could not have been starker.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is very underexplained. You read x, y, and z with no specific detail given. What do you want to say about yield curves? What were the negative effects of Liz Truss's budget? What is the link between economics, finance, and daily life - very much not stark from how you've described it.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Add specific detail about what you learned from yield curves, specify the negative effects of Liz Truss's budget, and explain the link clearly

feedback_items.weak_passage: I want to study Economics and Finance to channel my curiosity about how societies and economies function. By focusing on Econometrics, Microeconomics and Financial Markets, I hope to understand how individuals, societies, markets and countries make decisions and adapt in complex conditions.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Don't capitalise subject names. This part is reading like intro part 2? We still haven't moved on from why you want to study the subject. Then you just list modules and a random sum-up sentence about individuals, societies, etc. You definitely need to re-do this whole section.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Suggested revision: 'For a Lloyds Bank Challenge, I analysed customer data to set credit limits. I found it fascinating that financial institutions consider __x__ alongside more typical credit history to determine the interest rate they offer each individual. Reading ___x____, from the BoE showed me the effects of x on y.... (Then properly develop and explain whatever you've chosen to focus on....)'

feedback_items.weak_passage: I learnt quantitative methods to model abstract concepts such as scale of extreme poverty vs. impact of covid
feedback_items.your_feedback: Not that great to talk in vague terms 'quantitative methods' to model 'abstract concepts'. Cut out first part. Suggested start: 'As a finalist in a Maths for Morality course, I began by calculating the relative scores of.... (extreme poverty versus impact of covid) - what does this mean? What exactly are you calculating here... what relative scores - this needs much better set up or rest of your section doesn't make sense.'
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Cut vague opening and clarify exactly what you were calculating and comparing

feedback_items.weak_passage: However, this produced numbers of varying magnitude - a problem I solved by use of logarithmic scaling
feedback_items.your_feedback: You haven't properly set up this problem - what numbers are being produced here? What are you exploring here! How would you even begin to calculate the 'impact' of AI?
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Properly set up what problem you were solving and what numbers you're referring to before jumping to the solution

feedback_items.weak_passage: Follow up research into modified Cobb-Douglas function (Y = A(t).K^α.L^β.H^γ), showed me the use of capital, labour, human capital and tech factor
feedback_items.your_feedback: This part is very messy - don't capitalise economics. This genuinely doesn't make any sense, sounds like you haven't understood. 'Follow up research into modified Cobb-Douglas function' - follow up to what? Your essay? Why were you following up? No point mentioning formulas here because you haven't used it to develop your point further.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Clarify what you were following up on, why you were doing this research, and use the formula to develop a point rather than just listing it

feedback_items.weak_passage: Modelling tech factor as function of time with different rates of AI growth revealed accelerated output growth, often touted by several sources.
feedback_items.your_feedback: What does this mean? Where did you find this? Can you mention the sources? 'Revealed accelerated output growth, often touted by several sources' is too vague.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Specify which sources and be clear about what you actually found

feedback_items.weak_passage: However, on more research I realised limits of this model due to multicollinearity
feedback_items.your_feedback: Multicollinearity = correlation between independent variables in regression, not a limitation of growth accounting. This section needs a complete rewrite.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Remove incorrect use of technical term and properly explain the actual limitations you identified

feedback_items.weak_passage: I picked Mintzberg's interpretation of managerial job as mix of Interpersonal, Informational and Decisional roles and combined it with ideas of "exposure" and "complementarity"
feedback_items.your_feedback: Can you rewrite this to make your conclusions clearer? The actual topic is interesting but it's just the phrasing. Explain this framework more clearly. What was your question? What was your conclusion? What was your argument?
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Suggested revision: 'For Oxford University's Big Think essay competition, I created a framework for understanding ___x___, and won the E&M category. I focussed on Mintzberg's interpretation of managerial jobs as falling into interpersonal, informational, and decisional roles. I referenced an IMF research paper "AI and the Future of Work" to argue that ____x____. I wanted to find if ___x____. To do this, I assigned exposure and complementarity to the coordinate axes and placed Mintzberg's roles in different quadrants. I found that ____ and argued _______.'

feedback_items.weak_passage: Separately, I explored how disruptive patents incentivize tech expansion while creating consumer welfare loss. Using Farrel and Shapiro's framework from "The Economics of information technology" to quantify consumer surplus
feedback_items.your_feedback: Under-explained and there is no context given here. So many ideas all listed and not explained - shows lack of understanding. 'I found that while this drives R&D spending... it risks monopoly pricing' is like AS level economics knowledge and not at all a surprising conclusion. What does 'highlighting regulators' crucial role' mean here - very basic/generic.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Provide proper context, explain the framework in detail, and reach more sophisticated conclusions than basic economics

feedback_items.your_feedback: This paragraph is fine. Just the ending is a bit wordy and generic - not the end of the world just not a huge value add.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Tighten the ending to remove wordiness
feedback_items.strong_passage: While studying market failure in Economics, I was struck by the contrasting views of Eugene Fama & Robert Shiller on markets. To explore Fama's ideas, I used Essentials of Investments by Bodie/Kane to build a CAPM project. Working through questions in the book helped me grasp the concept of returns, variance, covariance, and the use of log returns. I used R/RStudio to download dataset of monthly returns of five stocks alongside Fama-French factors to run excess-return regressions and estimate CAPM (alpha, beta) for each stock and then evaluated fit of charts against actual data. This exercise made it fascinating to read Shiller's critique of efficient market hypothesis as he challenges assumption of frictionless markets and highlights information asymmetry.
feedback_items.why_strong: Demonstrates independent learning, coding skills, quantitative analysis, and engagement with contrasting theoretical perspectives in finance
